comment.author: 35654828@N00
comment._content: Says "Collins" makes a base hit on the photo. Perhaps Eddie Collins of the Athletics?

comment.author: 47245599@N08
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Land of freedom, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A note says that the Bain caption (which does include the name of Collins) was corrected for a new title on the basis of SABR research in 2006. I imagine the SABR experts were not convinced that it is actually of Collins. Scores for the 3rd game (at www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/NY1/NY1191310090.shtml) don't help as far as a bunt is concerned, I don't think.

comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content:
The batter does look like Eddie Collins, however.

Notice how short left field was,279 ft.  The right field line was only 258 feet.  However, centerfield was 483 ft.  This photo shows the fourth incarnation of "The Polo Grounds" which was for a short time named Brush Park after Giant owner John Brush.  The Polo Grounds was actually in three different places.  It was rebuilt in the same place after a fire in 1911.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
I think I understand the confusion.  The date on the negative is the date of game 3, but the negatives typically have a date a day or more later than the day the photo was taken.  If this is actually from game one (10-7), Collins did bunt for a base hit in the 9th.
However, there is probably no way of knowing if this is actually from game one.
